Hello everybody

I started dabbling in AI abouit twenty years ago on and off. For a
while  I thought that genetic programming could be an avenue to follow
(Koza). However lately I came across the NEAT concept which I found
fascinating since it combines the best of both worlds (neural networks
+ evolution).
I have followed the discussions you guys have with interest. I think
that since the recurrent neural networks are intractable
mathematically, apart from some very special cases (hopfield), one can
only speculate and experiment to learn things.
Regarding the discussion about the recurrency question and what a RNN
can or can not do there is a very interesting paper which proves that
there is a turing machine for every RNN and vice-versa. Since anything
that is computable can be achieved with a turing machine so can it
through an RNN. The trick is to find it :)
http://www.uwasa.fi/stes/step96/step96/hyotyniemi1
